title: Is f(x) = x³-3x injective given f:R->R? - Quora

response.answer_text: Is [math]f(x)=x^3-3x[/math] injective, given that [math]f:\R\rightarrow\R[/math]? Take the derivative of the function. You’ll straightaway notice that the sign of the derivative changes at some points. [math]f(x)=x^3-3x[/math] [math]\implies f'(x)=3x^2-3=3(x-1)(x+1)[/math] [math]f'(x)>0\qquad x\in\R\setminus(-1,1)[/math] [math]f'(x)\leq0\qquad x\in[-1,1][/math] That’s enough evidence to state that the function is not injective.  It is clearly not an injective function.

The function is said to be injective if f(a)=f(b) i.e if we put any two values (eg. a & b) from domain of a function and we get an answer f(a)=f(b) then the function is injective or one one Here f(x) is given below from R to R so, Let 1 & -1 belongs to domain of a function, hence f(1) & f(-1) is, f(1)=(1)^3–3*(1)=1–3=-2 f(-1)=(-1)^3–3*(-1)=-1+3=2 Since,f(a)!=f(b) so f:R-->R is not an injective function
